title: François Robichon de La Guérinière
text:
François Robichon de La Guérinière (1688–1751) was a French riding master who had a profound effect on accepted methods for <a href="horse%20training">horse training</a>, and one of the most influential writers on the art of <a href="dressage">dressage</a>.
History.
De La Guérinière was born on 8 May 1688 at <a href="Essay%2C%20Orne">Essay</a>, near <a href="Alen%C3%A7on">Alençon</a> in <a href="Normandy">Normandy</a>, France. He spent most of his early years in Normandy. Although his brother Pierre des Brosses de La Guérinière directed the Académie d'équitation in <a href="Caen">Caen</a>, originally established in 1594 by another French master, <a href="Antoine%20de%20Pluvinel">Antoine de Pluvinel</a>, de La Guérinière's most influential instructor was de Vendeuil.
In 1715, de La Guérinière received his diploma as an , and he began as a director of an equestrian academy in Paris, a position which he held for 15 years and which earned him a reputation as an instructor and rider. This led to an appointment by the <a href="Grand%20%C3%A9cuyer%20de%20France">Grand écuyer de France</a>, <a href="Prince%20Charles%20of%20Lorraine">Prince Charles of Lorraine</a>, as Directeur du Manège des Tuileries in 1730. He held the position of Equerry to <a href="Louis%20XIV">Louis XIV</a> until his death in 1751.
Riding theories.
De La Guérinière is credited for the invention of the <a href="shoulder-in">shoulder-in</a>, which he called the "alpha and omega of all exercises"; he was the first to describe it. His treatise "L'École de Cavalerie", "The School of Horsemanship", which was published in parts between 1729 and 1731, and as a complete work in 1733, is an important book on the training of the horse, detailing equitation, veterinary treatment, and general horsemanship. This book has become an important text for the <a href="Spanish%20Riding%20School">Spanish Riding School</a> of Vienna.
De La Guérinière gave exercises to increase suppleness and balance of the horse, and a progressive schooling system to reach an overall goal: a light, obedient, calm horse that was a pleasure to ride. De La Guérinière is also credited with the invention of the <a href="flying%20change">flying change</a> and the <a href="counter-canter">counter-canter</a>.
In his book, "Ecole de Cavallerie" (Paris, 1733), de La Guérinière stresses the use of few <a href="riding%20aids">aids</a> and punishments while riding. He advises the use of the shoulder-in at all <a href="horse%20gait">gaits</a>, including the <a href="gallop">gallop</a>. De La Guérinière states the rider must also have a good seat in order to have a soft, light hand, and makes several references to <a href="William%20Cavendish%2C%201st%20Duke%20of%20Newcastle">William Cavendish, 1st Duke of Newcastle</a>.
